div1.p: Russell states that Wakeman's death was mistakenly attributed to yellow fever by the newspapers.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Laura Armistead Carter, March 21, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel.
Russell,

JOHN A. FERRELL, M.D.
VICTOR G. HEISER, M.D.
H. H. HOWARD, M.D.
WILBUR A. SAWYER, M.D.
THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
INTERNATIONAL HEALTH DIVISION
FREDERICK F. RUSSELL, M.D., DIRECTOR
61 BROADWAY, NEW YORK
CABLE ADDRESS “ROCKFOUND”
SCIENTIFIC DIRECTORS
-----
RUFUS COLE, M.D., CHAIRMAN
EUGENE L. BISHOP, M.D.
LOUIS I. DUBLIN, Ph.D.
WADE H. FROST, M.D.
FREDERICK F. RUSSELL, M.D.
WILSON G. SMILLIE, M.D.
C.-E. A. WINSLOW, Dr. P.H.
March 21, 1929.
Dear Miss Carter:
div1.p:
I was glad to receive your note of March 15,
1929 in which you ask about Dr. Wakeman.

Dr. Beeuwkes has just returned and told me
about Dr. Wakeman's illness. It was not yellow fever and
had no relation to yellow fever whatsoever. The news-
paper people got the matter very badly mixed up. His
illness was one which he might have had equally well, so
far as I can judge, in the United States. That does not
make his loss any the less, but it is unfortunate that
many people would consider our yellow fever campaign even
more dangerous to the personnel than it really is.

I am glad that you and Dr. Frost are getting on
so well. I am looking forward in the near future to see-
ing the completed manuscript.
div1.closer:
With best wishes, I am
Very sincerely yours, F F Russell Miss Laura A. Carter
The Westmoreland
2122 California Street NW
Washington, D.C.
